quoteFirst: he said he had opened his ears to our councils and would observe them strictly, and that our words had made his heart glad. he requested that we would accept this mear and colt which he gave in token of his determination to pursue our advise.--
title: The Journals of Lewis and Clark, 1804-1806
author: Lewis, Meriwether, 1774-1809; Clark, William, 1770-1838

quoteLast: we saw a figure approaching our trenches and by his style we knew it to be our dear old major.  On he came in spite of the fire.
title: "Holding the line"
author: Baldwin, Harold, 1888-1982

quoteFirst: Despite his avoidance of vegetables and an excessive consumption of meat, he suffered little from indigestion, except during a few days of fierce sirocco wind off Madeira. He breakfasted about 10 on meat and wine, and remained in his cabin reading, dictating, or learning English, until
quoteLast: , when he played games and took exercise preparatory to dinner at 5. After a full meal, in which he partook by preference of the most highly dressed dishes of meat, he walked the deck for an hour or more.
title: The Life of Napoleon I (Complete)
author: Rose, J. Holland (John Holland), 1855-1942

quoteLast: , and without the slightest difficulty found the beast's trail exactly where the Mexican had said we should. Before this time I had killed an odd bear or so in Colorado, and had had some little experience in unraveling the trail of game.

quoteFirst: --The engine bucked yesterday, for a change, so we 'phoned to Meredosia and secured the services of the _Celine_, a gasoline launch of five-horse-power. She started at once, but arriving in sight of Naples she also stopped and lay two hours before she condescended to resume.
quoteLast: we got under way, the _Celine_ pushing, with a V of two-by-fours for her nose and a strong rope reaching from her stern to each after corner of the scow. Then our own engine awoke, and ran all day, as if she never knew what a tantrum was.
title: The Houseboat Book: The Log of a Cruise from Chicago to New Orleans
author: Waugh, W. F. (William Francis), 1849-

quoteLast: , passed a large corvette-built ship, close upon the wind, with royals and skysails set fore and aft, under English colors.  She was standing south-by-east, probably bound round Cape Horn.

quoteLast: we continued our course along the bank of the river, to the northward, till eight o clock, when we reached Nayemow; here the hospitable master of the town received us kindly, and presented us with a bullock. In return, I gave him some amber and beads.
title: Life and Travels of Mungo Park
author: Park, Mungo, 1771-1806

quoteFirst: On the day I left Karma’s,
quoteTime: about three o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: I was overtaken by a party of men, the leader of whom happened to be, as I afterwards found, the chief of the district of Hor-tosho, through which I was then travelling. They accosted me. I saw in the glint of the chief’s eyes something that told me that he had half a mind to suspect me.
title: Three Years in Tibet
author: Kawaguchi, Ekai, 1866-1945

quoteLast: we finally set off in open water and sailed till eight or so in the evening; the water was then closed, and we were compelled to haul the fleet over flat ice to open water on the other side. But here, too, our progress seemed blocked, and as the current was against us we pitched the tent."

quoteTime: about three o'clock in the afternoon

quoteFirst: Well, the road was clear, and
quoteTime: about three o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: I was at St Denis, though it took me a long two hours to get from there to Paris, for the road was blocked with commissariat waggons and guns of the artillery reserve, which was going north to Marmont and Mortier. You cannot conceive the excitement which my appearance in such a costume made in Paris, and when I came to the Rue de Rivoli I should think I had a quarter of a mile of folk riding or running behind me.

quoteFirst: SIR: I have the honor to report that yesterday,
quoteLast: , the lieutenant commanding and seven men of the advance pickets imprudently advanced from their posts and were captured.  I ordered Major Ricker, of the Fifth Ohio Cavalry, to proceed rapidly to the picket-station, ascertain the truth, and act according to circumstances.
